repnme.cdata!:
Bulgaria - Private Investment and Export
            Finance Project and Agricultural Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The two projects are rated
            unsatisfactory. The key lessons learned are: 1) Financial
            intermediary lending is likely to fail, if implemented
            before basic macroeconomic and structural reforms are firmly
            in place. 2) Projects relying on planned reforms or on the
            impact of jointly implemented projects are built on shaky
            ground. 3) The impact of technical assistance should not be
            over-estimated. 4) The lack of financially strong, well
            managed and supervised banks, able to assess and manage
            risks, is a problem impossible to resolve in the short run;
            during the life time of a credit line project. 5) Where
            institutional weaknesses are systemic, any efforts to
            strengthen individual institutions may be futile. 6) Credit
            line operations require deeper appraisal and early
            contracting of a large number of well performing financial
            intermediaries. 7) Credit line projects require fully
            committed and participating counterpart institutions. 8) If
            the design of a project turns out not to fit a given
            situation, the project should be redesigned or canceled as
            quickly as possible.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Agricultural Development Project
            will be the Bank's first operation in the agricultural
            sector. It is designed to improve access of the private
            sector to medium- and long-term credit for investments in
            primary agriculture and agribusiness. Medium- and long-term
            foreign exchange resources will be made available through
            World Bank approved commercial banks to finance imports of
            farm machinery and other equipment needed in the
            modernization of the sector. The project will be implemented
            over a four-year period and will consist of two major
            components: 1) the credit component will finance medium- and
            long-term sub-loans exclusively to private investors for
            eligible investments. These will be imports of fixed and
            movable assets and associated permanent working capital for
            financially and economically viable investments in
            agriculture, agribusiness and related activities such as
            transport, trade, handicrafts, rural tourism, and associated
            services; 2) the institutional development assistance to the
            participating financial intermediaries will include: a)
            technical assistance to strengthen their capacity in the
            appraisal and supervision of sub-loans, and b) the financing
            of part of the office and other equipment needed for modernization.
